Specific Details: Engagement with Minister on the topic of rising harms of drugs in a European and Irish context. Significant focus on the harms of the black market. Briefing on educational approaches to cannabis and harm reduction. We also discussed solutions to certain problems from a regulatory perspective based on evidence and data from other jurisdictions, as well as topics relating to the Citizens Assembly on drug use & the national oversight committee for current drugs strategy.
DPOs Lobbied: Frank Feighan|Minister of State|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Engagement with Minister on the topic of rising harms of drugs in a European and Irish context. Significant focus on the harms of the black market. Briefing on educational approaches to cannabis and harm reduction. We also discussed solutions to certain problems from a regulatory perspective based on evidence and data from other jurisdictions, as well as topics relating to the Citizens Assembly on drug use & the national oversight committee for current drugs strategy.
Intended Results: To highlight the rising harms of black market substances, to begin engagement with the department of health and to query about how 'non-problematic' drug users will be represented in the terms of reference of the upcoming Citizens Assembly.
Lobbying Activities: 6th of December meeting in the Department of Health, ran for about 45 mins.|Meeting|1

Specific Details: Share an independent study*, conducted by King’s College London, commissioned by the UK Office for Health Improvement and Disparities in the Department of Health and Social Care, found that smokers who switched to vaping experience a “substantial reduction” in their exposure to toxic substances that cause cancer, lung and cardiovascular disease. However, researchers strongly advise non-smokers to avoid smoking or vaping.
DPOs Lobbied: Stephen Donnelly|Minister|Department of Health::Frank Feighan|Minister of State|Department of Health
Subject Matter: Share an independent study*, conducted by King’s College London, commissioned by the UK Office for Health Improvement and Disparities in the Department of Health and Social Care, found that smokers who switched to vaping experience a “substantial reduction” in their exposure to toxic substances that cause cancer, lung and cardiovascular disease. However, researchers strongly advise non-smokers to avoid smoking or vaping.
Intended Results: Inform public representatives of the survey.
Lobbying Activities: Seek meeting with the Ministers to show how banning flavoured vapes would not be effective in stopping teen use of vapes.|Email|1

Subject Matter: To develop North/South Trade in the Boarder regions
